occurrences.line_text: As euery one had cause of good or ill.
That vnto euery person knew her part;
Against the storme of euery dreadfull stoure:
To hide the metall, which yet euery where
To damne him selfe by euery euill name;
And euery one gan homeward to resort.
Where searching euery part, her well assured,
She gan a fresh to chafe, and grieue in euery vaine.
In euery thing, thou oughtest first to know,
What was the poyse of euery part of yore:
That euery one doe know their certaine bound,
And swat, and chauf'd, and proued euery way:
And rudely stroke at him on euery side:
To which there did resort from euery side
From euery coast and countrie vnder sunne:
That euery one his daunger did eschew.
To greet his guerdon vnto euery knight,
Fast bound on euery side with iron bands,
And heaped strokes so fast on euery side,
And euery while that mighty yron man,
Basted with bends of gold on euery side,
She hewd, she foynd, she lasht, she laid on euery side.
Each hour did seeme a moneth, & euery moneth a yeare.
In euery place, and euery place thought best,
In euery place, and euery place thought best,
On euery side of his embatteld cart,
Seeking by euery way to make some breach,
Snatching at euery thing, doth wreake her wrath
Both ouer rockes, and hilles, and euery place,
That by his powre oppressed euery one,
That euery matter worse was for her melling,
And whiles he her pursued euery where,
Next that ye Ladies ayde in euery stead and stound.
That euery action doth them much commend,
Whose euery act and word, that he did say,
But wayt on him in euery place and part.
Yet was he courteous still to euery wight,
In all assaies to euery errant Knight,
And euery way did try, but all in vaine:
And euery litle limbe he searcht around,
And euery part, that vnder sweathbands lay,
But when he lookt about on euery syde,
On euery side, and beat about him round;
Sought to encompasse him on euery side,
Their ranckling wounds, & euery day them duely drest.
Giue salues to euery sore, but counsell to the minde.
Contagious poyson close through euery vaine,
Whylest euery ioynt for dread of death did quake,
Of euery wight, that were not too infest,
Began to tremble euery limbe and vaine;
At euery step vppon the tiptoes hie,
And all the way he went, on euery syde
To giue him ground, and shift to euery side,
That euery foote did tremble, which did tread,
And euery body two, and two she foure did read.
They towards euening wandring euery way,
Whooping, and hallowing on euery part,
And perfectly well shapt in euery lim,
My lambes doe euery yeare increase their score,
My limbes in euery shade, to rest from toyle,
And drinke of euery brooke, when thirst my throte doth boyle.
The mightie ones, affrayd of euery chaunges dread.
And euery day, her companie to gaine,
With the faire Pastorella euery day,
And euery euening helping them to fold:
Of euery blaste, and sayling alwaies on the port.
All which do him assayle on euery side,
Through euery place, with restlesse paine and toile
Yet still he him did follow euerywhere,
The Eugh obedient to the benders will,
He gan t'efforce the euidence anew,
Gaue euidence, that they were all betrayd,
Demaunded, I made plaine and euident,
We may not chaunge (quoth he) this euil plight,
And homebred euill ye desire to heare,
Where he slept soundly void of euill thought,
May seeme the wayne was very euill led,
For in his lustlesse limbs through euill guise
Of that fowle euill, which all men reproue,
If old Aveugles sonnes so euill heare?
In euill houre thy foes thee hither sent,
The euill stownd, that daungerd her estate,
She said, Ah dearest Lord, what euill starre
Is not enough thy euill life forespent?
And be partakers of their euill plight,
For feare of euill fates, but burnen euer bright.
Such and such euill God on Guyon reare,
Ah puissaunt Lords, what cursed euill Spright,
Ne any euill meanes she did forbeare,
And euill meanes, with which she doth enrage
So euill thing to seeke vnto their ayd,
For euill is at hand him to offend.
Indeed (then said the Prince) the euill donne
For neuer was she in so euill cace,
To loose long gotten honour with one euill hond.
As fearing euill, that pursewd her fast;
Ne euill thing she fear'd, ne euill thing she ment.
Ne euill thing she fear'd, ne euill thing she ment.
What vncouth fit (said she) what euill plight
Then doth this wicked euill thee infest,
The growing euill, ere it strength haue got,
Sith a sore euill, which this virgin bright
But this sad euill, which doth her infest,
Or euill spright, that in her doth such torment breed.
To her no euill thought, nor euill deed;
To her no euill thought, nor euill deed;
Of euill, may more notably be rad,
To hoord vp heapes of euill gotten masse,
By which he feareth euill happen may:
So th'euill thinkes by watching to preuent;
One may his iourney bring too soone to euill end.
That euill matched paire they seemd to bee:
And marshalling the euill ordered traine,
The seedes of euill wordes, and factious deedes;
Would afterwards afresh the sleeping euill reare.
Dissembling his disease and euill plight;
Both they vnwise, and warelesse of the euill,
That doth ill cause or euill end enure:
And with his axe him smote in euill hower,
Of th'euill plight, in which her dearest brother
Fro loue to hate, a change of euill choise:
For euill deedes may better then bad words be bore.
And litle prays'd his labours euill speed,
The one right feeble through the euill rate
The euill case in which those Ladies lay;
He gan of them inquire, what euill guide
That all the cares and euill which they meet,
As if some blame of euill she did feare,
To damne him selfe by euery euill name;
To see an helpelesse euill, double griefe doth lend.
For neuer wight so euill did or thought,
Thereto he hath a groome of euill guize,
The spoile of peoples euill gotten good,
Sir Artegall vndid the euill fashion,
What euill hap to Marinell betid,
Which in the rudenesse of that euill plight,
As by his modest semblant, that no euill ment.
Was ment to her, that neuer euill ment in hart.
That thorough euill rest of this last night,
Eyther for th'euill, which he did therein,
Of euill words, and wicked sclaunders by him shed.
But this, what euer euill she conceiued,
To please the best, and th'euill to embase.
This euill manner, which ye here maintaine,
The cause of all this euill, who was slaine
There left on ground, though in full euill plight,
Me then to be full base and euill borne,
And feele compassion of his euill plight
Hath ioyn'd one euill, which doth ouerthrow
The seede of all this euill first doth spring,
For when the cause, whence euill doth arize,
So shall you soone repaire your present euill plight.
Those euill tidings to their Lord to shew.
Maintaine this euill vse, thy foes thereby to foile.
Perdie (said he) in euill houre it fell,
Ere long they came, whereas in euill tyde
With all the euill termes and cruell meane,
For they themselues were euill groomes, they sayd,
All these, and many euils moe haunt ire,
Of treble good: good growes of euils priefe.
Deare Sonne, great beene the euils, which ye bore
Doth not, I weene, so many euils meet.
That may compassion of their euils moue?
Thus of their euils as they did discourse,
Cares not what euils hap to wretched wight;
Good hart in euils doth the euils much amend.
Good hart in euils doth the euils much amend.
In euils counsell is the comfort chiefe,
Louely Pasithee, kinde Eulimene,
And token true to old Eumenias,
And that old man Eumnestes, by their propertis.
White hand Eunica, proud Dynamene,
Iust Dice, wise Eunomie, myld Eirene,
And faire Euphaemus, that vpon them go'th
Which Phison and Euphrates floweth by,
Great Ganges, and immortall Euphrates,
The first of them hight mylde Euphrosyne,
Cymo, Eupompe, and Themiste iust;
Of which none is to me vnknowne, that eu'r was seene.
Now like a Bull, Europa to withdraw:
And shouldred hath the Bull, which fayre Europa bore.
Of swift Eurotas, or on Cynthus greene,
By him begot of faire Eurynome,
Eurypulus, that calmes the waters wroth;
Kept by a cowheard, hight Eurytion,
The rich Cteatus, and Eurytus long;
First through the Euxine seas bore all the flowr of Greece.
Ancient Ogyges, even th'auncientest,
In which the fearefull ewftes do build their bowres,
So farre as Ewghen bow a shaft may send,
Royall examples of her mercies rare,
Yet stuck, with carkasses exanimate
But soone as Titan gan his head exault,
And ample volume, that doth far excead
Ne durst behold: his stature did exceed
But stings and sharpest steele did far exceed
When they would striue dew reason to exceed;
To all licentious lust, and gan exceed
Is sacrilege, and doth all sinnes exceed;
Doth course of naturall cause farre exceed,
Are still emongst them song, that far my rymes exceed.
Is death, or if that ought do death exceed,
Such chaunces oft exceed all humaine thought:
Whether in beauties glorie did exceede;
And filthy lust exceede all woman kind,
That he which was the last, the first did farre exceede.
Doth she exceede the rest of all her race;
All other Dames to haue exceeded farre;
And in excesse exceeded her owne might;
Yet shortly gaynd, that losse exceeded farre:
As farre exceeded men in their immeasurd mights.
His wonder farre exceeded reasons reach,
Whose depth exceeded not three cubits hight,
Both deadly sharpe, that sharpest steele exceeden farre.
Ne let it seeme, that credence this exceedes,
Herein the noblesse of this knight exceedes,
That many Princes she in wealth exceedes,
As enuying her selfe, that too exceeding shone.
Exceeding shone, like Phoebus fairest childe,
And that great Princesse too exceeding prowd,
Eternall prouidence exceeding thought,
Yet so exceeding was the villeins powre,
Shapt like a Ladies head, exceeding shone,
For so exceeding shone his glistring ray,
Thereat he roared for exceeding paine,
Whose wondrous faith, exceeding earthly race,
His feeble sence, and too exceeding shyne.
Exceeding rage enflam'd the furious beast,
That loud he yelded for exceeding paine;
That their exceeding merth may not be told:
But would be dazled with exceeding light.
And now exceeding griefe him ouercame,
Who in her loosenesse tooke exceeding ioy;
And in his hand two darts exceeding flit,
Exceeding wroth was Guyon at that blow,
And shewd of richesse such exceeding store,
As ouercome with too exceeding might,
Of men, then beasts. But ï¿½ th'exceeding grace
Against two foes of so exceeding might,
Neither vnseemely short, nor yet exceeding long.
A labour huge, exceeding farre my might:
So fowle and vgly, that exceeding feare
The same he snatcht, and with exceeding sway
His whirling charet, for exceeding feare:
The royall riches and exceeding cost,
Exceeding much the state of meane degree,
Exceeding riches and all pretious things,
Exceeding griefe that wound in him empight,
To make exceeding mone, as they had bene vndonne.
Exceeding mone, and curst that cruell chaunce,
With thought whereof, exceeding mad he grew,
To wexe exceeding wroth, and him ared
Whereat he gan to wex exceeding wroth,
She was astonisht with exceeding dreed,
Goodly adorned, and exceeding faire:
Exceeding wroth therewith the virgin grew,
Exceeding wroth thereat was Blandamour,
That daz'd the eyes of all, as with exceeding light.
Thereat exceeding wroth was Satyran;
And farre renowmed through exceeding fame;
Witnesse th'exceeding fry, which there are fed,
Which is but narrow, but exceeding long;
The fourth Ecastor, of exceeding might;
Is so exceeding furious and fell,
Are so exceeding spacious and wyde,
For his exceeding courtesie, that pearst
And makes exceeding mone, when he does thinke
And for exceeding griefe which inly grew,
Did wexe exceeding sorrowfull and sad,
He shewed semblant of exceeding mone,
Exceeding all the rest in powre and hight;
Whereof exceeding glad, he to him drew,
Are so exceeding venemous and keene,
Exceeding much the measure of mans stature,
Whereat Excesse exceedingly was wroth,
But Florimell exceedingly did fret,
He was therewith exceedingly dismayd;
He thereat wext exceedingly astound,
Till it the pitch of highest prayse exceeds:
Exceld at Athens all the learned preace,
They haue exceld in artes and pollicy,
That in the same she farre exceld all other.
Or if that any else did Ioue excell:
Drawne of faire Pecocks, that excell in pride,
It Merlin was, which whylome did excell
And striue your excellent selfe to excell;
Both Silo this, and Iordan did excell,
Of second sister, who did far excell
To clime aloft, and others to excell:
Did th'other far in workmanship excell;
That all this other worlds worke doth excell,
But those three monstrous stones doe most excell
Yet he at last contending to excell
Did far excell, but was most famous hight
All other pleasant places doth excell,
For he in counterfeisance did excell,
All the braue knights, that doen in armes excell,
Fayrest of faire, that fairenesse doest excell,
In which their powre all others did excell;
The prize of her, which did in beautie most excell.
In which to her that doth the most excell,
But it in shape and beautie did excell
And endlesse memorie, that mote excell,
Which did in noble deedes of armes excell,
For she all liuing creatures did excell;
And to maintaine, that she all others did excell.
Approu'd that day, that she all others did excell.
Both her and eke all others to excell:
And they that most in boldnesse doe excell,
Which doe all worldly riches farre excell,
And doe adorne your Court, where courtesies excell.
So farre the meane of shepheards to excell,
The gentle knight, as he that did excell
But he, that did in courtesie excell,
Seem'd all the rest in beauty to excell,
All other lesser lights in light excell,
Chrysaor that all other swords excelled,
And added grace vnto her excellence:
That men beholding so great excellence,
That hath so soone forgot the excellence
For fear through want of words her excellence to marre.
Thou haue it lastly brought vnto her Excellence.
To doe to so diuine a beauties excellence.
Still when her excellencies he did vew,
Th'Eternall brood of glorie excellent:
That flowre of faith and beautie excellent.
Of wondrous worth, and vertue excellent,
And striue your excellent selfe to excell;
There is no one more faire and excellent,
Doth florish in all beautie excellent:
For so must all things excellent begin,
Whom late in chace of beautie excellent
And both encreast her beautie excellent;
Faire Helene, flowre of beautie excellent,
Whose beautie each of them thought excellent,
To see the thing, that seem'd so excellent,
Bewrayd the signes of feature excellent:
Which round about her moue in order excellent.
A wicked hag, and Enuy selfe excelling
Excelling much the meane of her degree;
That none could read, except she did them teach,
Except Cleopolis: so heard I say
For th'antique world excesse and pride did hate;
And in excesse exceeded her owne might;
Whereat Excesse exceedingly was wroth,
That much she feard his mind would grow to some excesse.
It forth would breake, and gush in great excesse,
In case his burning lust should breake into excesse.
With which he swallowd vp excessiue feast,
For Steward was excessiue Gluttonie,
Which hauing swallowd vp excessiuely,
Or his exchange, or freedome might be wrought.
Exchanged out of one into an other feare.
And doest not it for ioyous court exchaunge,
To make one great by others losse, is bad excheat.
To leaue to him that Lady for excheat,
Endite I would as dewtie doth excite;
From hope of heauen hath thee excluded quight,
And others quite excluded forth, did ly
Not onely her excluded late at night,
After I had ten yeares my selfe excluded
Excludes from fairest hope, withouten further triall.
Shall drowne all Holland with his excrement,
My former hardnesse first I faire excusd;
Good cause of mine excuse; that mote ye please
The knights were willing all things to excuse,
At which his vaine excuse they all gan smile,
Certes (sayd he) ye mote as now excuse
Which she forgot, whereby excuse to make:
Feigning full many a fond excuse to prate,
And little had for his excuse to say,
Thus did the courteous Knight excuse his blame,
But none of those excuses could take place;
Alwayes, to execute her stedfast doome,
That they might execute her iudgements wise,
Who executes her wicked will, with worse despight.
Tho when she had his execution stayd,
He should his flale to finall execution bend.
In execution of her lawlesse doome,
Who scarcely yet from former feare exempted,
And greatly shunned manly exercise,
In goodly thewes, and godly exercise:
And wondred at his endlesse exercise,
And exercise most bitter tyranny
Seeking aduentures hard, to exercise
And ciuile armes to exercise no more:
Both of the way, and warlike exercise,
For thy fierce arrowes, them to exercize,
Might not reuiue desire of knightly exercize.
Not fit for speedy pace, or manly exercize.
The dreadfull speare and shield to exercize:
And turne his arrowes to their exercize:
Calling men to their daily exercize,
Either for fame, or else for exercize,
Keeping their sheepe, or games to exercize,
To worke such shame. Therefore I thee exhort,
I fonder loue a shade, the bodie farre exild.
And cride to heauen, from humane helpe exild.
Emongst wild beasts and woods, from lawes of men exilde.
Into a caue from companie exilde,
Farre from all peoples prease, as in exile,
Of Mona, where it lurked in exile;
Whiles that from heauen he suffered exile.
Exiled her, that all the world spake shame.
But ah, her expectation greatly was deceau'd.
His expectation to despaire did turne,
For certaine losse of so great expectation.
And bring with him his long expected light?
Where I expected one with shield and spere,
Which I expected long, now turnd to sad annoy?
Expecting euer, when some foe she might descry.
There lay Sir Scudamour long while expecting,
Forwasted all their land, and them expeld:
Wrath, gealosie, griefe, loue do thus expell:
Then he another and another did expell.
Seemeth that such wild woods should far expell
doth sleepe from him expell.
And wemens loue did from his hart expell,
All twenty tride in warres experience long;
She caused him to make experience
And through the long experience of his dayes,
The maisters of his long experiment,
Ne then of guile had made experiment,
For both were skild in that experiment,
As Pilot well expert in perilous waue,
Was so expert in euery subtile slight,
Thereto he was expert in prophecies,
Expert in battell and in deedes of armes;
In swimming be expert through waters force to pas.
Ere that I in her guilefull traines was well expert.
And passing well expert in single fight,
In warlike feates th'expertest man aliue,
Shalbe expird of Britons regiment.
In which the wombes of women do expire,
Which he from hellish entrailes did expire.
Affection, I doe languish and expire.
And doe not rather wish them soone expire,
But till the horned moone three courses did expire.
And with that word him strooke, that streight he did expire.
And fates expired could renew againe,
As when iust time expired should appeare.
By all the meanes she mote it best explaine:
Taken in hand th'exploit, being theretoo
His whole exploite, and valorous emprize,
Vnto his first exploite he did him selfe apply.
In this exploite, me needeth to declare,
And to all great exploits them selues inclind:
Exploits made Rome to quake, stout Guendolen,
And braue exploits which great Heroes wonne,
Dare not for dread his hardy hand expose,
The which his mother vainely did expound,
Which to expresse, he bends his gentle wit,
Did labour liuely to expresse the same,
But liuing art may not least part expresse,
Whose face discouered, plainely did expresse
To doe the message, which I shall expresse.
To whom Sir Artegall gan to expresse
Sith he cannot expresse his simple minde,
But all her hinder parts did plaine expresse
And gan her forme and feature to expresse,
Expressing well his nature, which the same did wield.
From point to point, as is before exprest,
Let nought be hid from me, that ought to be exprest.
Against the forreine Morands he exprest;
And th'idle breath all vtterly exprest:
Forreine ensamples, it to haue exprest?
Then like a king he was to her exprest,
where Loues spoyles are exprest.
Her name was VVomanhood, that she exprest
Whose soueraine powre is herein most exprest,
Or did his life her fatall date expyre,
That wild the damzell rise; the day did now expyre.
Till time the tryall of her truth expyred:
Not well awakt, or that some extasie
Which suddein fit, and halfe extatick stoure
What stately building durst so high extend
That shall their conquests through all lands extend,
And all the while he red, she did extend
Yet holding fast twixt both his armes extended
Stretcht on the ground in monstrous large extent,
Aboue the water were on high extent,
To know, and them t'enlarge with long extent,
Yet both are of thy haplesse hand extinct,
Which to extirpe, he laid him priuily
And hath for twelue huge labours high extold,
Through strong oppression of his powre extort;
Whether by might extort, or else by slight deceaued.
But now by force extort out of her hand,
And with extorted powre, and borrow'd strength,
Restraining stealth, and strong extortion;
She heard, that she was lineally extract:
For maruell of that accident extreame;
That Lion-like shall shew his powre extreame.
Too truely tryde in his extreamest state;
Till that at length, in his extreamest neede,
And had he not in his extreamest need,
Or drawne forth from her by diuine extreate.
That of his puissance tryall made extreeme;
Tho vp he started, stird with shame extreme,
That shortly brent into extreme desire,
